data.title: Selection indicator in 3D needs improvement
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Current way of indicating which objects are selected is not very useful, the bounding box corners are not very noticeable (actually not visible in light scenes) and it's often hard to see if I selected mesh or lamp even.
Would suggest some sort of coloured outline around mesh objects and maybe sprite display change for lamps and stuff.
Additional benefit from outline is when working with stacked, intersecting meshes. User can then see borders of the object he manipulates and it's easier for him to see what he is doing.

data.title: Hard to select objects in 3D view when zoomed out
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When zoomed out it's impossible to select some smaller objects. I'm not talking about 5px objects of course, they are reasonably big on screen to be selectable by user.

data.title: Script Editor clears unsaved changes when changing application
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux (Ubuntu)
Godot 2.0.2

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
If I edit a script and don't save it, then change for sec to other application window like web browser, unsaved text disappears.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create script.
Write something.
Change application.
Go back to Godot.

data.title: Shader node materials don't show updated normal-map data (in the viewport) when saved
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Win10 64 bit; 24 Gigs RAM; third-gen i7 CPU; ATI HD 7xxx GPU.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When changing the normal map data in a shader material (using the visual node editor). The edited data will initially show like it should in the viewport. However, when you save the material, the visuals you get in the viewport will revert back to how it looked when the editing was started (but the new data _is_ saved). The only way to really update it for good is to then exit to the projects window and reload the project in question.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Download the project file, go to its shader node setup, play around with the normal map data a little, then save the material. Instant revert in the viewport (visually at least). Exit to the projects window and re-open the project to see it updated like it should be.

**Link to minimal example project** **(optional but very welcome):**
http://www.mediafire.com/download/3mucchbbonshdbz/Terrain%282%29.zip

data.title: Node Multi-Edit can't attach script to multiple nodes
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I've tried to add same script to multiple nodes using multi-edit feature and properties editor. It didn't worked had to add them manually to each node :)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create many nodes.
Select them.
Turn ON multi-edit/
Go to properties and try to attach script to them.

data.title: Drop obsolete platforms
data.body:
As discussed in #4347, dropping the Flash and NACL platforms, that are no longer maintained.

Closes #4347.

data.title: Shapes generated by CollisionShape helper node are not named properly
data.body:
The CollisionShape helper node doesn't call set_name() on on shape it makes,
which lead to problems identifying them.

data.title: A rigidbody without a collisionobject 2d does not react to torque
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Tested on Ubuntu 16.04

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
A 2D rigid-body was added, and an off-center impulse was applied. A polygon was added as a child of the rigidbody to see rotation. When run, the rigidbody remained unrotated. Then I added a collisionshape, and the torque suddenly did affect the rigidbody.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Paste attached scene and script into empty godot project. Run the scene. Obsereve rotation. Delete CollisionShape2D. Run scene again. Observe no rotation.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[RigidBodyIssue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/234613/RigidBodyIssue.zip)

data.title: Animation Tree Player improvements (mostly GUI)
data.body:
We need to have the following improvements to ATP:
1. There is a feature called filters. If you don't know, you can't avoid using it if you blend
   several animations or using oneshot node for things like blinking, as it limits scope of your animations.
   We need to have separate filters "node" from blend/oneshot nodes in GUI.
   This node will allow us eventually implement general animation filtering, which will make
   animation composition hardships go away. Basically all important functionality
   is already implemented, this is small readjustment.
   Nedd to mention we don't want to attach this "node" to Animation node.
2. Animation node needs to have multiple output in GUI. This
   can be generated into multiple animation "nodes" for each output, or some other things,
   but this have to be done, as lots of nodes with the same animation really clutters scene output.

Imagine you have "blink" animation and "breathe" animation.
First one goes to oneshot node, second is looped, they blend to all animations like, walk, stand.
sit, lay down, idle13, whatever. If you have hundred main animations ,only these 2 detail animations will
make your setup into 300 nodes hard to navigate and manage.
Internally this can be the same as now, but for GUI something needs to change.
1.  The filter editor for animations with many tracks (like skeletal animations) looks like mess.
   It is very hard to navigate. Probably it should be replaced by something useful, but probably
   if possible the existing one can be improved by a few simple things:
   - Add search for simple substring with immediate display (like quick search in some apps)
     not requiring press Enter after each result, just reducing output with additional character entered.
2. Add "invert selection", "select all", "unselect all" buttons
3. Disable treeish view (probably a checkbox with immediate reaction), replacing it with plain table), that would really help with bones,

data.title: Movable collision object for collision avoidance
data.body:
We all seen that Godot lacks collision bodies which could be controlled by bones.
So it should have feature of static body (not movable on its own), but
still collide and prevent collisions from occurring (collision avoidance).

While we can sorta implement this for triggering (i.e. hit boxes ,etc.)
using Area but that will not solve a problem of collision avoidance.

Also we can manipulate positions of collision bodies within RigidBody from code.

This is more actual when  using bones, as other cases can be handled by adding many collision shapes. But you might want to switch them on and off depending the animation you run.

But for character animation this is different, as overall game experience depends on collision quality.

data.title: scons use CPPFLAGS as well as CCFLAGS to compile c code?
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux 4.5.1-1-ARCH

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Added a "-std=c++14" CPPFLAGS into env, and compile godot.
It seems CPPFLAGS also be used to compile c code?
Which is ok for gcc toolchain, but for **clang** it has some trouble with this flag
`error: invalid argument '-std=c++14' not allowed with 'C/ObjC'`

_How to compile c code without CPPFLAGS?_

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer API
AnimationTreePlayer woes again :)
data.body:
Well, we have a funny documentation about AnimationTreePlayer function types.

Like track_get_key_value() which returns Variant and labelled
as void in the class docs. You can't really work with A-T-P until you read C++ code.
That is really a bad thing. Also animation filter handling is not documented while it is
very simple and useful concept. Also filter editor is a piece of crap.

Saying that, I had really good time digging all that. Thank you guys!

data.title: Shader Graph - Deleting a node in the node editor auto-selects and auto-moves another node.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Win10 64 bit; 24 gigs RAM; third-gen i7 CPU; ATI HD 7xxx GPU

**Issue description** **(what happened, and what was expected):**
When deleting a node in the visual node editor, the editor will often auto-grab another node and move it with the cursor. This is not desired and noticeably impacts usability.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open the example file, open the node tree for the material, select a node, delete the node. Notice how another one automatically sticks to your cursor for no apparent reason.

**Link to minimal example project** **(optional but very welcome):**
[Bugs.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/233840/Bugs.zip)

data.title: Make export GUI debug toggle more obvious
data.body:
I can't seem to find a way/option to **hide the console/commandline window** when running the game in Release mode. I personally saw this on Windows but also on HTML5.

It is extremely important not to have that window visible when publishing a game as the end-user does not need to see this, or have any access to it.

_Using Godot 2.0.2_

data.title: Custom Company/GameName folder for OS.get_data_dir() instead of just "Godot" on Desktop?
data.body:
Currently Godot is using a "Godot" master path in Appdata directory for user data.

However it'd be better if we could change the path so it would be either something like,

```
%appdata%/<CompanyName>/<GameName> or 
%appdata%/<GameName>
```

So instead of:
`C:/Users/Alex/AppData/Roaming/Godot/app_userdata/TestGame`

on Windows, it would be,

`C:/Users/Alex/AppData/Roaming/My Company/My Game/`

So you could organize your games' data under a Company or a custom branded directory etc.

I propose a field in the Project Settings that would allow for a path like `[ My Company/My Game  ]` that'd be always parented to the %appdata% directory.

Tested on Windows. Mac & Linux possibly have this issue as well. Especially Linux since I know files are most likely stored under`~/.config/`, and it probably needs to be `~/.config/<CompanyName>/<GameName>`. On Mac it should be in the Library/Application Support folder like `~/Library/Application Support/<CompanyName>/<GameName>`

_Using Godot 2.0.2_

data.title: Game window + splash screen should be centered on game start
Version Information in Project Settings for Windows applications
data.body:
Application executables on Windows supports additional metadata called **Version Information**. The info is available in detail to the user by right clicking and choosing Properties > Details, it also shows the info under the .exe name in the Explorer and Taskbar entry and used for some System dialogs.

I can't seem to find a way to add this via the Project Settings so I am requesting it.
We need fields like:
- Description
- Version
- Product
- Company
- Copyright

_Using Godot 2.0.2_

data.title: Disabling Window Resize feature should not disable the minimize button as well
data.body:
Tested on Windows. Mac & Linux possibly have this issue as well.

Disabling the **Resizable** feature through Project Settings or OS.set_window_resizable(false) should not disable BOTH maximize and minimize button, but just maximize.

_Using Godot 2.0.2_

data.title: A couple problems with the Splash Screen on Desktop targets
data.body:
Tested on Windows. Mac & Linux possibly have this issue as well.

**The splash screen has the following issues:**
1. You can't disable it completely in the Project Settings, there should be an option for it (the dev might not want to show it or the game loads very fast so there is no need for it)
2. Appears non-centered, window should be centered (if you center the game window manually, the splash screen flickers to the left top and it looks bad)
3. The splash screen window shows the Godot icon (the little icon top-left), it needs to show the game icon
4. Add more customization in Project Settings? Like, no border for the splash screen window?, Fullscreen splashscreen? Delay in ms? etc.?

_Using Godot 2.0.2_

data.title: Label / RichTextLabel \n not parsed when text is set via Text/Bbcode fields in inspector
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 7

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Whenever I add \n to Labels/RichTextLabels (the standard text line break) via the Text/Bbcode fields in the inspector, it is never parsed... I can only get it to parse the linebreak if I set/add the text via code
This is especially confusing for newer users, as after trying to add it in using these fields when experimenting and it not working, I believed there was no linebreak character support for Labels/RichTextLabels

**Steps to reproduce:**
Attempt to add a linebreak (\n) to a Label/RichTextLabel via the Text/Bbcode fields in the inspector

data.title: The 3D scene view does not do a full refresh after re-importing with edits to the .dae file.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Win10 64 bit; 24 gigs RAM; third gen i7 CPU; ATI HD 7xxx GPU

**Issue description** **(what happened, and what was expected):**
Editing the scene in a 3D program (in this case Blender), exporting the .dae file, and doing the re-import step does not do a full refresh of either the original scene itself or the scenes containing the edited data as an instance (instead you have to close the scene and re-open it). The only area where the refresh works as it should is when a scene file is being created for the first time.

What's expected is that a full view refresh would happen so the edited data immediately becomes visible. This was the case in Godot 1.x, but this has generally been a nuisance in Godot 2.x and hurts usability (even though it's not a showstopper with the quick workaround mentioned).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a 3D scene file, import it to Godot, then edit the 3D scene file and use the re-import dialogue in Godot. Notice how there's no immediate change.

Now close the scene and re-open it, the edits should be there as it should be.

data.title: Shader script editor appears out of nowhere when backing out of the shader nodes
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Win10 64 bit; 24 gigs RAM; third gen i7 CPU; ATI HD 7xxx GPU

**Issue description** **(what happened, and what was expected):**
In the original version 2 release for Godot, going into the shader node setup, then clicking the back arrow just closes the nodes window without opening something else. Newer builds (done in the last week) now show the shader script editor (regardless of whether I want to do any editing or not).

Then, returning to the shader does not close the script window, so now you have two additional windows instead of just one. I can see the use of having the raw code made available, but whether or not the script window is visible should be a user option rather than something done automatically by Godot (unless of course you're in the regular custom shader options and you explicitly use the script field in the _reference_ area).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open the file, select the mesh instance, go to the material editing buttons via the material override menu, go to the shader tree editing via the shader menu, then back out of the tree editing with the back button.

**Edit:: Example file to try it with**
[Bugs.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/233844/Bugs.zip)

data.title: Android TV remote control not handled by Godot 2.0.2_stable
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**

Godot 2.0.2_stable official, Win64
Android-TV 5.1 lollipop

**Issue description** 

Pressing the AndroidTV remote control buttons does not generate any input events.

The tv-remote "back" button exits the godot game, but the tv-remote DPAD and OK (DPAD_CENTER) don't work.
Pressing tv-remote numpad does not work neither.

According to the AndroidTV doc, the tv-remote is supposed to work as a DPAD, and the "OK" button (at the center of the tv-remote DPAD) should return a KEYCODE_DPAD_CENTER that is generally treated as a BUTTON_A. 

On the other hand, when I plug an USB XBOX 360 controller into the TV, the game controller works pretty well.

Just in case, here you have some resources about android game controllers and tv-remote :
https://github.com/chuckjr/AndroidTV_TVInputDeviceTest/blob/74cf52e7f02d24efba770566c8aa0ecb352164a1/app/src/main/java/com/stinkless/tvinputdevicetest/activity/MainActivity.java
http://developer.android.com/training/game-controllers/controller-input.html
https://developer.amazon.com/appsandservices/community/post/TxDMC4ZG5XCTCN/10-Tips-for-Remote-and-Controller.html

**Steps to reproduce:**

Run the 

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

```
test.scn
    Control (+script)
        Label
```

```
extends Control

func _ready():
    set_process_input(true)

func console(string):
    var label = get_node("Label")
    label.set_text( label.get_text() + " ; " + string )

func _input(event):
    console(""+str(event.type)+", "+str(event.device)+", "+str(event.ID) )

```

After click TouchScreenButton which causes a change scene, debugger show error "Child Process Connected".
TextureButton not show this error.

2) Create "TouchScreenButton"
3) Connect button with function when "pressed"

`get_tree().change_scene("res://scenes/game.tscn")`

4) After change scene debugger show error "Child Process Connected"

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Resources text format usage
data.body:
I'm using script files to generate some scenes of my projects. It works fine with your text format, except when it comes to asset management. Unless I've missed it, I haven't been able to find documentation about the file format for `tex`, `atex`, `fnt` and similar binary formats, which makes them quite hard to correctly generate. Looking at the issues and the source code, I've been able to find references to a `tres` format, but I'm not sure if it's what I'm looking for, since it doesn't seem to be used for textures and fonts in the example files.

Basically, I'd like to be able to write a file with the following:

```
[texture]
image_path = /assets/directory/myImage.png
image_data = 45A45D21B454BADDCFFDE88==
```

Is that possible, one way or the other?

I'm aware that it would increase the project size and loading time, and that not every resource needs to be imported first (but some are, such as fonts, so why not do it for everything since a script will do it anyway), but I'd still like to know if it's possible. Being able to dynamically generate resources pre-build would be a tremendous help.

data.title: AnimationPlayer / AnimatedSprite frame and offset key aren't set when scrubbing timeline
data.body:
When I'm working on an animation using `AnimatedSprite`, I often have to change sprite's `frame` during animation, as well as its `offset` ( which is the rotation pivot ). These tracks are set to discrete ( not continuous ), and my expectation is that when I'm scrubbing the timeline, to preview the animation, the `frame` and `offset` keys would take effect immediately when time hits them. Instead, the sprite is updated when the timeline is dragged past them, on the next frame/step.

This makes animating extra cumbersome, because of the discrepancy between what I see on the scene, and the keys I see at current time in the timeline.

Additionally, clicking on the timeline between two keys on a track set to discrete doesn't apply current track value, so it's a total mess on the screen.

data.title: When AnimationPlayer is seeked, certain values aren't set correctly.
data.body:
This happens on tracks whose interpolation type is set to discrete. **Setting AnimationPlayer's time by clicking on timeline, or programmatically using `seek` between two keys, doesn't update the value to that of the previous key.** But this works correctly if the track is continuous, and values are interpolated.

Example:
- track `sprite:frame` is set to discrete and has a key at time `0.0s` with value `10`, it has another key at time `5.0s` with value `11`.
- My sprite's current frame is set to some other value, say, `20`, and player's time is at `10.0s`
- Clicking on timeline at `2.5s` should set sprite's frame to last / previous key, namely one at `0.0s` - frame `10`, but nothing happens. Other, continuous tracks all get set correctly, resulting in chaotic / incorrect display of the animation.
- The only way to see animation correctly is to manually drag / rewind animation to `0.0s`, and then drag the time slider over to `2.5s`. This is a huge time killer, and makes editing very cumbersome.

In my case, character body parts are separate, and have different frames for "straight", "bent at elbow", "holding a gun" etc., so sprite frame number, and sprite offset are set to discrete. I've wasting a ton of time needlessly scrubbing the animation back to last frame, just so I can see it displayed correctly.

My game also saves character state, along with current animation name, and current animation time. When game is restored, the animation is often somewhere in progress, and what I see is mangled / incorrectly positioned body parts at wrong frames.
![screen-shot-2016-04-23-at-7 33 12-pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6539713/14764781/b430dd1c-098a-11e6-9947-3815e35fe013.jpg)
